items.title: A/B testing
items.description: A method of comparing two versions of a webpage, email, or feature to determine which performs better based on user behavior.

items.title: Acquisition cost (CAC)
items.description: Customer Acquisition Cost is the total expense required to acquire a new customer, including marketing, sales, and advertising costs.

items.title: Agile development
items.description: An iterative approach to software development that promotes collaboration, adaptability, and continuous delivery.

items.title: API (Application Programming Interface)
items.description: A set of protocols and tools that allow different software applications to communicate and share data.

items.title: Backlog
items.description: A prioritized list of tasks, features, or bugs waiting to be developed or addressed in future sprints.

items.title: Beta release
items.description: A pre-launch version of a software product released to selected users for testing and feedback.

items.title: Bootstrapping
items.description: Building and growing a company using personal savings or internal revenue rather than external funding.

items.title: Churn Rate
items.description: The percentage of customers who cancel or stop using a subscription service during a given period.

items.title: Cloud computing
items.description: The delivery of computing services including servers, storage, databases, and software over the internet instead of local infrastructure.

items.title: Conversion rate
items.description: The percentage of users who complete a desired action (such as signing up, purchasing, or upgrading) out of the total number of visitors.

items.title: CRM (Customer Relationship Management)
items.description: Software that helps businesses manage interactions with existing and potential customers to improve relationships and retention.

items.title: Customer lifetime value (CLV or LTV)
items.description: The total revenue a business can expect from a customer over the entire duration of their relationship.

items.title: Dashboard
items.description: A visual interface that displays key metrics, analytics, and performance indicators in real time for easy monitoring and decision-making.

items.title: Data analytics
items.description: The process of collecting, analyzing, and interpreting data to uncover patterns, trends, and insights that guide business decisions.

items.title: Data migration
items.description: The process of transferring data from one system, platform, or storage type to another, often during upgrades or software transitions.

items.title: Engagement rate
items.description: A metric that measures how actively users interact with your product, content, or platform, often through clicks, time spent, or feature usage.

items.title: Enterprise SaaS
items.description: Software-as-a-Service designed for large organizations with advanced scalability, security, and customization needs.

items.title: Error Log
items.description: A record of issues, bugs, or failures that occur within a system, used by developers to diagnose and resolve problems.

items.title: ETL (Extract, Transform, Load)
items.description: A process for collecting data from various sources, transforming it into a usable format, and loading it into a database or data warehouse.

items.title: Event tracking
items.description: Monitoring specific user actions within a product (such as clicks or form submissions) to analyze behavior and optimize experiences.

items.title: Evergreen content
items.description: Content that remains relevant and valuable over time, often used in marketing and SEO strategies to attract long-term traffic.

items.title: Feature flag
items.description: A software switch that allows teams to enable, disable, or test features without deploying new code.

items.title: Funnel
items.description: A marketing or sales model that illustrates the stages users go through before converting into paying customers.

items.title: Freemium model
items.description: A business model offering a basic product for free while charging for premium features or advanced functionality.

items.title: Full stack developer
items.description: An engineer skilled in both front-end and back-end technologies, capable of building complete web applications.

items.title: Functional requirements
items.description: Specific behaviors or functions a system must perform, defining how software should operate from the user's perspective.

items.title: Feedback loop
items.description: A process of gathering user feedback, analyzing it, and applying insights to improve the product or customer experience.

items.title: Gamification
items.description: The use of game-like elements (such as badges, points, or progress bars) in software to increase user engagement and motivation.

items.title: Go-to-Market (GTM) Strategy
items.description: A plan that outlines how a company will introduce a product to the market, reach target customers, and achieve competitive advantage.

items.title: Headless CMS
items.description: A content management system that separates the backend (content repository) from the frontend (presentation layer), enabling flexible content delivery.

items.title: Help desk Software
items.description: Tools that manage customer support requests, tickets, and communication channels efficiently.

items.title: Ideation
items.description: The creative process of generating, developing, and refining new ideas for products, features, or improvements.

items.title: Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS)
items.description: A cloud computing model that provides virtualized computing resources like servers, storage, and networking on demand.

items.title: JavaScript
items.description: A core programming language used to build dynamic and interactive web applications, essential for modern SaaS interfaces.

items.title: Journey mapping
items.description: A visual representation of the steps users take when interacting with a product, used to identify pain points and opportunities for improvement.

items.title: KPI (Key Performance Indicator)
items.description: A measurable value that shows how effectively a company or team is achieving its business objectives.

items.title: Kanban
items.description: An agile project management method that visualizes work on a board to improve flow, efficiency, and task prioritization.

items.title: Knowledge base
items.description: A centralized collection of articles, guides, and FAQs designed to help users find answers and learn independently.

items.title: Kubernetes
items.description: An open-source system for automating the deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications.

items.title: Landing page
items.description: A standalone webpage designed to convert visitors into leads or customers through focused messaging and a clear call-to-action.

items.title: Lean Startup
items.description: A methodology focused on building products quickly, testing hypotheses, and learning from user feedback to reduce waste.

items.title: Lifetime Value (LTV)
items.description: The total revenue a business can expect from a single customer throughout their relationship with the company.

items.title: Low-Code Platform
items.description: A development environment that enables users to create software with minimal manual coding through drag-and-drop tools and visual interfaces.

items.title: Load Balancing
items.description: A method of distributing network or application traffic across multiple servers to improve speed, reliability, and uptime.

items.title: Machine Learning (ML)
items.description: A subset of artificial intelligence that enables systems to learn and improve from data without being explicitly programmed.

items.title: Managed hosting
items.description: A hosting service where the provider handles setup, maintenance, security, and performance optimization on behalf of the user.

items.title: Market fit (Product-Market Fit)
items.description: The stage where a product successfully meets the needs and demands of its target audience, resulting in strong user growth and retention.

items.title: Marketing automation
items.description: Software that automates repetitive marketing tasks such as email campaigns, lead nurturing, and social media management.

items.title: Metrics dashboard
items.description: A visual overview of key performance indicators (KPIs) and analytics used to track progress and business health.

items.title: Microservices
items.description: An architectural approach where software is built as a collection of small, independent services that communicate through APIs.

items.title: Minimum viable product (MVP)
items.description: The simplest version of a product that allows teams to test core assumptions and gather feedback from early users.

items.title: Mobile optimization
items.description: The process of designing and adjusting websites or applications to deliver a seamless experience on mobile devices.

items.title: Monthly recurring revenue (MRR)
items.description: A key SaaS metric that represents predictable monthly income from active subscriptions.

items.title: Net promoter score (NPS)
items.description: A customer satisfaction metric that measures how likely users are to recommend a product or service to others.

items.title: No-code platform
items.description: A development environment that allows users to build apps and workflows without writing code, using visual interfaces instead.

items.title: Notification system
items.description: A feature that sends alerts or updates to users about important events, changes, or actions within a product.

items.title: Niche market
items.description: A focused segment of a broader market with specific needs that a product or service is designed to serve.

items.title: Onboarding flow
items.description: A step-by-step process designed to help new users get started and experience the product's core value quickly.

items.title: Open source
items.description: Software whose source code is publicly available for modification, enhancement, and distribution.

items.title: Opt-In
items.description: A user's consent to receive communication, notifications, or marketing materials, typically via email or in-app prompts.

items.title: Outbound marketing
items.description: Marketing efforts that actively reach out to potential customers through channels like ads, cold emails, or events.

items.title: Optimization
items.description: The practice of improving a system, design, or process for better performance, speed, or conversion.

items.title: Paywall
items.description: A system that restricts access to content or features until the user pays or subscribes.

items.title: Persona (User persona)
items.description: A fictional profile representing a key segment of your audience, used to guide product design and marketing strategies.

items.title: Pipeline
items.description: A structured process of stages that leads prospects from initial contact to conversion, often used in sales and development contexts.

items.title: Plugin
items.description: A piece of software that adds specific functionality to an existing application or platform.

items.title: Prototype
items.description: An early, simplified version of a product used to test concepts and gather feedback before full development.

items.title: Product-Led growth (PLG)
items.description: A go-to-market strategy where the product itself drives user acquisition, conversion, and expansion.

items.title: Quality assurance (QA)
items.description: The process of systematically testing software to ensure it meets quality standards and is free from defects.

items.title: Query
items.description: A request made to a database to retrieve or manipulate specific information.

items.title: Quota
items.description: A set limit or target for performance, usage, or sales within a defined period.

items.title: REST API
items.description: Representational State Transfer API - a web service architecture that uses standard HTTP methods to enable communication between systems.

items.title: Rate limiting
items.description: A technique to control the number of requests a user or system can make to an API or service within a specific time period.

items.title: Real-time collaboration
items.description: A feature that allows multiple users to work on the same document or project simultaneously with instant updates visible to all participants.

items.title: Refactoring
items.description: The process of restructuring existing code without changing its functionality to improve readability, maintainability, or performance.

items.title: Regression testing
items.description: Testing that ensures previously working features continue to function correctly after new changes or updates are made.

items.title: Release management
items.description: The process of planning, scheduling, and controlling the deployment of software releases to production environments.

items.title: Remote work
items.description: A work arrangement where employees perform their job duties from locations outside the traditional office, often from home.

items.title: Repository
items.description: A storage location for software code, typically using version control systems like Git, where developers can store and manage project files.

items.title: Revenue recognition
items.description: The accounting principle that determines when revenue should be recorded in financial statements, important for subscription-based businesses.

items.title: Rollback
items.description: The process of reverting a system or application to a previous version or state when a new deployment causes issues.

items.title: Runtime
items.description: The period during which a program is executing, or the environment in which software runs, including necessary libraries and dependencies.

items.title: Retention rate
items.description: The percentage of customers who continue using a product over a specific period, indicating satisfaction and loyalty.

items.title: Roadmap
items.description: A visual plan outlining upcoming product features, improvements, and long-term goals.

items.title: ROI (Return on Investment)
items.description: A metric that measures the profitability or effectiveness of an investment relative to its cost.

items.title: Release Notes
items.description: Documentation detailing new features, bug fixes, or updates included in a product release.

items.title: Responsive design
items.description: A design approach that ensures websites and applications automatically adjust to different screen sizes and devices.

items.title: TAM
items.description: The total revenue opportunity available for a product or service if 100% market share is achieved.

items.title: Tech stack
items.description: The combination of software technologies and tools a company uses to build and run its applications.

items.title: Trial conversion rate
items.description: The percentage of users who convert from a free trial to a paid subscription.

items.title: Telemetry
items.description: Data collected from software usage to monitor performance and user behavior.

items.title: Uptime
items.description: The percentage of time a service or application is operational and available to users.

items.title: User journey
items.description: The path a user takes from first interaction with a product to achieving their goal.

items.title: Usage-based pricing
items.description: A pricing model where customers pay based on the amount they use a service.

items.title: UX (User experience)
items.description: The overall experience and satisfaction a user has while interacting with a product.

items.title: Viral coefficient
items.description: A metric that measures how many new users each existing user generates through referrals.

items.title: Venture capital (VC)
items.description: Funding provided by investors to startups with high growth potential in exchange for equity.

items.title: Webhooks
items.description: Automated messages sent from an app when a specific event occurs, enabling integrations between software.

items.title: Workflow automation
items.description: The use of software to automate repetitive tasks and processes within an organization.

items.title: White-label SaaS
items.description: A SaaS product that can be rebranded and sold by another company as its own.

items.title: XaaS (Anything-as-a-service)
items.description: An umbrella term for services delivered over the cloud, including SaaS, PaaS, and IaaS.

items.title: XML (Extensible markup language)
items.description: A format for structuring and exchanging data between systems.

items.title: Yield
items.description: The return or revenue generated by a product, feature, or marketing channel.

items.title: Year-over-year (YoY)
items.description: A growth metric comparing performance for the same period in consecutive years.

items.title: Young company metrics
items.description: KPIs used to measure growth and traction in early-stage startups.

items.title: Zero downtime deployment
items.description: Deploying software updates without disrupting service availability for users.

items.title: Zapier Integration
items.description: Connecting apps and automating workflows using the Zapier platform.
